t: Woe*pn to the land of whirring wings along*ld the rivers of Cush,

which*ln sends envoys by sea in*ld papyrus boats over the water. Go,*pn swift messengers, to*ln a people tall and smooth-skinned, to*ld a people feared far and wide, an*ln aggressive nation of strange speech, whose*ld land is divided by rivers.
All*pn you people of the world, you*ld who live on the earth, when*ln a banner is raised on the mountains, you*ld will see it, and*ln when a trumpet sounds, you*ld will hear it.
This*ln is what the Lord*s says to me: “I*ld will remain quiet and will look on from my dwelling place, like*ln shimmering heat in the sunshine, like*ld a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”

For,*ln before the harvest, when the blossom is gone and*ld the flower becomes a ripening grape, he*ln will cut off the shoots with pruning knives, and*ld cut down and take away the spreading branches.
They*ln will all be left to the mountain birds of prey and*ld to the wild animals; the*ln birds will feed on them all summer, the*ld wild animals all winter.

At*p that time gifts will be brought to the Lord*s Almighty from*pn a people tall and smooth-skinned, from*ld a people feared far and wide, an*ln aggressive nation of strange speech, whose*ld land is divided by rivers— the*p gifts will be brought to Mount Zion, the place of the Name of the Lord*s Almighty.
